keyTakeAways: Royal jewels worth over $100 million were stolen from the Louvre museum in Paris during a daylight robbery involving four masked thieves using a crane to break a window.
The stolen items included a tiara and earrings from Queen Marie-Amélie and Queen Hortense, and the crown of Empress Eugenie was reportedly left outside the museum.
The estimated economic loss was 88 million euros ($102 million), with the prosecutor emphasizing that this is dwarfed by the historical and cultural damage of the theft.
The theft occurred in just seven minutes at the Apollo Gallery, where France's remaining crown jewels are displayed, and involved a motorcycle getaway.

The Louvre's director, Laurence des Cars, has not publicly commented since the incident but is set to appear before the French Senate’s culture committee amid growing public and political concern over museum security.

A 24-year-old Chinese woman was detained in Barcelona after attempting to dispose of melted gold from a previous heist at the Natural History Museum, which involved stolen gold nuggets valued at over $1.5 million.
Thieves also stole items worth $7.6 million from a museum in Limoges, indicating a broader trend of museum security failures.
A 2019–2024 report by France’s Court of Auditors revealed persistent delays in security upgrades, with only a quarter of one wing of the Louvre covered by video surveillance.
Labour unions have criticized the reduction of security staff at the Louvre despite rising visitor numbers, which reached 8.9 million in 2023.
The Louvre, with over 8.7 million visitors in 2023, remains one of the world’s most visited cultural sites and a symbol of global heritage.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Royal jewels from the early 19th century, including pieces from Queens Marie-Amélie and Hortense and the crown of Empress Eugenie, were stolen in a daylight robbery at the Louvre museum in Paris. The theft, which took only seven minutes and involved four masked thieves using a crane to break a window and escape on motorcycles, has been estimated to cause $102 million in economic loss and profound historical damage. The Louvre director, Laurence des Cars, has not publicly commented, though she is set to appear before the Senate’s culture committee over growing concerns about security. A 24-year-old Chinese woman was arrested in Barcelona after attempting to dispose of melted gold from a prior heist at the Natural History Museum. The incident coincides with broader reports of security failures, including only a quarter of one wing of the Louvre being monitored by surveillance, and a lack of staffing despite rising visitor numbers. The Louvre, one of the world’s most visited cultural institutions, has faced mounting criticism over its inadequate security measures.
